event.name:
Angel Pharmacy
is founded
event.shortDescription: Angel Pharmacy is founded
event.fullDescription:
1654
Angel Pharmacy (Engel Apotheke) is founded in Darmstadt, Germany.

event.name: Jacob Friedrick Merck acquires Angel Pharmacy
event.shortDescription:
Jacob Friedrick Merck Acquires
Angel Pharmacy
event.fullDescription:
1668
The Angel Pharmacy is acquired by apothecarist Jacob Friedrick Merck. This is the beginning of the family's long tradition in the field of pharmaceuticals.

event.name: Johann Heinrich Merck influences Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
event.shortDescription: Johann Heinrich Merck influences the literary works of his close friend, author Johann Wolfgang von Goethe.
event.fullDescription: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe publishes his first major work, Götz von Berlichingen. Throughout his career Goethe was close friends with Johann Heinrich Merck, the son of Johann Franz Merck and brother of Johann Justus Merck. Johann Heinrich was well known for his friendship and influence on Goethe's work, which is acknowledged in Goethe's autobiography, Aus meinem Leben: Dichtung und Wahrheit  (From my Life: Poetry and Truth; 1811–1833).

event.name: Old Simes drug store opens
event.shortDescription: Old Simes Drug Store, later owned by H. K. Mulford Co., is established.
event.fullDescription: "Old Simes" Drug Store, a predecessor to H. K. Mulford Co., is established in Philadelphia, Pa.

event.name: George D. Rosengarten buys chemical manufacturing business
event.shortDescription: George D. Rosengarten buys out Zeitler & Seitler's chemical manufacturing business.
event.fullDescription:
1823
George D. Rosengarten buys chemical manufacturing business founded a year earlier in Philadelphia, Pa. The firm becomes Zeitler & Rosengarten. Over the next twenty years, the partnership changes hands several times.

event.name: E. Merck begins manufacturing
event.shortDescription: The E. Merck company begins manufacturing operations.
event.fullDescription:
1827
E. Merck, Darmstadt, starts manufacturing operations under the leadership of Heinrich Emanuel Merck.

event.name: Alpheus Phineas Sharp opens an apothecary
event.shortDescription: Alpheus Phineas Sharp opens an apothecary in Baltimore, MD.
event.fullDescription:
1845
Alpheus Phineas Sharp rents a two-story building on the southwest corner of Pratt and Howard Streets in Baltimore, Md., and starts his own business as a merchant and apothecary.

event.name: Ernst Schering opens pharmacy
event.shortDescription: Ernst Schering opens the Green Pharmacy.
event.fullDescription: Ernst Schering opens his own pharmacy in an industrial suburb of Berlin and names it the Grüne Apotheke (Green Pharmacy).

event.name: Louis Dohme joins A. P. Sharp's apothecary
event.shortDescription: Louis Dohme emigrates to Baltimore and begins work and study at A. P. Sharp's apothecary.
event.fullDescription:
1851
15-year-old Louis Dohme emigrates with his family to Baltimore from Obenkirchen, Germany, and shows up at A.P. Sharp's apothecary asking for a job. He is hired and begins his study of pharmacy.

event.name: E. Merck participates in the World Exhibition
event.shortDescription: E. Merck displays at World Exhibition in New York.
event.fullDescription: E. Merck hosts a display at the World Exhibition in New York City.

event.name: Louis Dohme and A.P. Sharp form Sharp & Dohme
event.shortDescription: Louis Dohme and A.P. Sharp become partners and form Sharp & Dohme.
event.fullDescription:
1860
Louis Dohme becomes a partner in A.P. Sharp's apothecary shop and the name of the firm is changed to Sharp & Dohme.

event.name: Rosengarten & Sons acquires two new partners
event.shortDescription: Harry B. Rosengarten and Adolph G. Rosengarten become partners in Rosengarten & Sons.
event.fullDescription:
1860
Harry B. Rosengarten and Adolph G. Rosengarten are admitted to the partnership of Rosengarten & Sons. Adolph G. later becomes Senior Major of the 15th Pennsylvania Cavalry and is killed at the battle of Murfreesborough, Tenn., in a cavalry charge.

event.name: Sharp & Dohme begins large scale manufacturing
event.shortDescription: Sharp & Dohme begins large scale manufacturing.
event.fullDescription: Sharp & Dohme begins large scale manufacturing of pharmaceuticals for other pharmacists throughout the U.S. Charles E. Dohme, younger brother of Louis Dohme, learns the process for large scale production of medicine while on assignment from the U.S. Secretary of War.

event.name: Schering AG is incorporated
event.shortDescription: Schering AG is incorporated.
event.fullDescription: Schering AG is incorporated.

event.name: Holtz and Glatz form Schering & Glatz
event.shortDescription: Schering AG's Holtz partners with Joseph Glatz to form Schering & Glatz.
event.fullDescription:
1876
Ernst Schering's colleague, J.F. Holtz, travels to the U.S. to exhibit at the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition. There he meets New York City drug importer Joseph Glatz, who soon forms a partnership with Holtz and renames his own company Schering & Glatz.

event.name: Sharp & Dohme opens New York branch
event.shortDescription: Sharp & Dohme opens New York branch.
event.fullDescription:
1885
Sharp & Dohme opens its first branch office in New York.

event.name: E. Merck opens New York branch
event.shortDescription: E. Merck opens a New York branch under the management of Theodore Weicker.
event.fullDescription:
1887
E. Merck opens its New York branch. It is managed by Theodore Weicker, who came straight from Darmstadt to establish the first office of E. Merck in the U.S.

event.name: Schering AG hires first research chemist
event.shortDescription: Schering AG hires its first research chemist, Albrecht Schmidt.
event.fullDescription: Schering AG hires its first research chemist, Albrecht Schmidt, in order to compete with other German companies producing proprietary compounds.

event.name: Sharp & Dohme opens Chicago, Ill. office
event.shortDescription: Sharp & Dohme opens Chicago, Ill. office.
event.fullDescription:
1888
Sharp & Dohme opens a branch office in Chicago.

event.name: Mulford Tablet Machine introduced
event.shortDescription: Henry Kendall Mulford patents a new tablet machine.
event.fullDescription: Henry Kendall Mulford patents the "Mulford Tablet Machine."

event.name: The first Merck Index published
event.shortDescription: The first Merck Index is published.
event.fullDescription:
1889
The Merck Index is first published. The Index is an encyclopedia of technical information on the pharmaceutical industry's products for pharmacists, doctors, dentists, veterinarians and chemists.

event.name: Merck & Co. is established
event.shortDescription: Merck & Co. is established at the U.S. office of E. Merck.
event.fullDescription: The U.S. office of E. Merck becomes a separate firm: Merck & Co. (The company is still partly owned by E. Merck.) This same year, George Merck travels from Germany to New York City to oversee company operations.

event.name: H. K. Mulford Co. is incorporated
event.shortDescription: H. K. Mulford Company is incorporated in Philadelphia, Pa.
event.fullDescription:
1891
H.K. Mulford Company is incorporated with Milton Campbell as president. Under his leadership, the company initiates its standardization of drug products as well as putting open formulas on labels. It also opens its laboratories to the inspection of scientifically qualified visitors, a practice almost unheard of when pharmaceutical formulas and production methods were jealously guarded "top secrets." At the time of its establishment, the company operated at 2132 Market Street in Philadelphia, Pa.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Merck exhibits at the Columbian Exposition
event.shortDescription: Merck exhibits at the Columbian Exposition.
event.fullDescription:
1893
Merck exhibits at the Columbian Exposition in Chicago, Ill.

event.name: George Merck marries Fredericke Schenck
event.shortDescription: George Merck marries Fredericke Schenck and settles in Llewellyn, N.J.
event.fullDescription:
1893
George Merck marries Fredericke Schenck. The couple purchases a home in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J., where they become neighbors and friends of the inventor Thomas Edison.

event.name: George W. Merck is born
event.shortDescription: George W. Merck is born.
event.fullDescription:
1894
George W. Merck, son of George Merck, is born in New York City.

event.name: Schering AG introduces its first prescription drug
event.shortDescription: Schering AG introduces its first treatment for urinary tract bacterial infections.
event.fullDescription: Schering AG begins to market its first prescription drug for the treatment of urinary tract bacterial infections.

event.name: H. K. Mulford Co. introduces first diphtheria antitoxin
event.shortDescription: H. K. Mulford Co. introduces first commercially produced diphtheria antitoxin produced in the U.S.
event.fullDescription:
1895
After over a year of research conducted in the lab of Dr. Joseph McFarland, H.K Mulford was able to offer for sale the first commercial diphtheria antitoxin produced in the U.S.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Merck & Co. opens pharmacy in Manhattan, N.Y.
event.shortDescription: Merck & Co. opens its own pharmacy in Manhattan, N.Y.
event.fullDescription:
1897
Merck & Co. opens its own stylish pharmacy in downtown Manhattan, N.Y. The Merck Pharmacy becomes known across the U.S. and Europe for exclusively selling drugs, candies or knick-knacks, which was unheard of at the time.

event.name: H.K. Mulford Co. introduces its smallpox vaccine
event.shortDescription: H.K. Mulford Co. introduces its smallpox vaccine.
event.fullDescription:
1898
H.K. Mulford's smallpox vaccine is introduced. The company prepares the vaccine as a glycerinated lymph that can be preserved when kept at the proper temperature without appreciably affecting its potency, allowing it to be stored until it needs to be shipped to the customer.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: First Merck Manual is published
event.shortDescription: The first edition of the Merck Manual is published.
event.fullDescription:
1899
The Merck Manual is first printed. It is known as the "Physician's Bible," containing the most up-to-date medical information of the day and providing medical professionals with vital information on diagnoses and treatments.

event.name: Charles E. Frosst & Co. is established
event.shortDescription: Charles E. Frosst & Co. is established.
event.fullDescription: Charles E. Frosst & Co. is established.

event.name: Merck acquires plant site in Rahway, N.J.
event.shortDescription: Merck acquires plant site in Rahway, N.J.
event.fullDescription:
1900
Merck acquires plant site in Rahway, N.J.

event.name: Rosengarten & Sons is incorporated
event.shortDescription: Rosengarten & Sons is incorporated in Pennsylvania.
event.fullDescription: Rosengarten & Sons is incorporated under the laws of the State of Pennsylvania, becoming Rosengarten & Sons, Inc.

event.name: Powers-Weightman-Rosengarten Company is established
event.shortDescription: Rosengarten & Sons, Inc. take over Powers & Weightman to form a new firm.
event.fullDescription: The plant and assets of Powers & Weightman are taken over by Rosengarten & Sons, and the name of the corporation is changed to Powers-Weightman-Rosengarten Company.

event.name: Scholl Manufacturing Co., Inc. is established
event.shortDescription: Dr. Scholl establishes his foot care company and introduces his first product.
event.fullDescription:
1907
Dr. William Mathias Scholl incorporates The Scholl Manufacturing Co. to manufacture and sell his first product, the Footeazer.

event.name: James J. Kerrigan begins working at Merck & Co.
event.shortDescription: The third president of Merck & Co, James J. Kerrigan, begins working at Merck at the age of 13.
event.fullDescription:
1907
James J. Kerrigan, born in New York and raised in Ireland, begins work at Merck as a messenger boy at the age of 13, shortly after returning to New York City. This is the beginning of a lifetime career with the company leading to the top executive level.

event.name: Abe Plough sells his first consumer product
event.shortDescription: Abe Plough begins selling Plough's Antiseptic Healing Oil, his first consumer product.
event.fullDescription:
1908
Abe Plough, a 16-year-old native of Memphis, Tenn., borrows $125 from his father to purchase carbolic acid, camphor and linseed oil, which he brews and bottles as his own liniment. Plough's Antiseptic Healing Oil is the start of Abe Plough's successful career in consumer products.

event.name: The Sandee Company is formed
event.shortDescription: The Sandee Company is formed by Sharp & Dohme.
event.fullDescription: Sharp & Dohme forms a holding company known as the Sandee Company.

event.name: Merck & Co. establishes its first foreign subsidiary
event.shortDescription: Merck & Co. establishes its first foreign subsidiary.
event.fullDescription:
1912
Merck & Co. sets up its first foreign subsidiary in Canada.

event.name: George W. Merck begins working for Merck & Co.
event.shortDescription: George W. Merck begins work at Merck & Co. in the packing and shipping department.
event.fullDescription:
1914
One year prior to his graduation from Harvard University, George W. Merck begins work with Merck & Co., the company established by his father. He starts in the packing and shipping department and gradually receives training in most departments and branches of the company.

event.name: Merck publishes its "Handy Book on Sanitation"
event.shortDescription: Merck publishes its "Handy Book on Sanitation" marketing its Creolin-Pearson disinfectant.
event.fullDescription:
1914
Merck first publishes its "Handy Book on Sanitation." The booklet offers useful information on the sanitary care of the household and domestic animals and guidelines for using Merck's Creolin-Pearson disinfectant.

event.name: The Maybelline company is founded
event.shortDescription: T. L. Williams founds the Maybelline cosmetics company with inspiration from his sister.
event.fullDescription: The Maybelline Company is founded by 19-year-old T. L. Williams. After seeing his sister Mabel applying Vaseline to her eyebrows and lashes, he develops and successfully markets a product to darken and add gloss to eyelashes that he names Lash-brow-ine.

event.name: Merck's legacy companies furnish medical supplies to the U.S. military
event.shortDescription: Merck's legacy companies, H. K. Mulford Co. and Powers-Weightman-Rosengarten & Co., furnish medical supplies to the U.S. military.
event.fullDescription:
1917
Milton Campbell and Henry Kendall Mulford of H. K. Mulford Co. and A.G. Rosengarten of Powers-Weightman-Rosengarten & Co. join the national group of manufacturers of pharmaceutical, chemical and disinfectant products furnishing medical supplies to the War and Navy Departments.

event.name: H. K. Mulford Co. establishes biologic depot in France
event.shortDescription: H. K. Mulford Co. establishes depot in France to supply biological products to the U.S. Army.
event.fullDescription:
1917
At the request of the Surgeon General of the U.S. Army, H. K. Mulford Co. establishes a biological depot behind the lines in France to provide adequate supplies of biological products for the U.S. Army.

event.name: U.S. Alien Property Custodian seizes Merck & Co. stock
event.shortDescription: The U.S. Alien Property Custodian seizes Merck & Co. stock and sells it at public auction.
event.fullDescription: Federal Judge A. Mitchell Palmer, who was recently appointed Alien Property Custodian, announces that the U.S. Government will seize several companies with German connections, including Merck & Co. George Merck turns over the company's stock owned by the German members of the family and runs the company as if it were his own absolutely. Nevertheless, Palmer decides to sell Merck stock at public auction.

event.name:
H. K. Mulford Co.
supplies U.S. military
with vaccines
during WWI
event.shortDescription: H. K. Mulford Co. supplies U.S. Army and Navy with millions of vaccines during WWI.
event.fullDescription:
1914-1918
H. K. Mulford Co. supplies the U.S. Army and Navy with millions of vaccines and serums for certain diseases throughout World War I. During this time, the director of the Biological Laboratories at Glenolden, Dr. Parker Hitchens, becomes director of all U.S. Army Laboratories.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: H. K. Mulford Co. keeps horses hyperimmunized for production of Antipneumococcic Serum
event.shortDescription: H. K. Mulford Co. keeps hundreds of horses hyperimmunized and ready for production of large quantities of Antipneumococcic Serum
event.fullDescription:
1917-1918
Throughout the final two years of the first World War, Mulford Laboratories keeps hundreds of horses hyperimmunized with Types I, II, and III pneumococci, capable of producing 20,000 doses of Antipneumococcic Serum Poly-valent per week.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Hagan Corporation is founded
event.shortDescription: Hagan Corporation is founded. The company's primary product is Calgon.
event.fullDescription:
1918
Hagan Corporation is organized by John M. Hopwood and Thomas A. Peebles and specializes in the development of automatic controls to regulate the supply of fuel and air to boiler furnaces. Through a collaborative effort between Hagan Corporation and the Pittsburgh Experiment Station of the Bureau of Mines, Dr. Ralph E. Hall discovers that the unique water conditioning properties of the chemical "sodium hexametaphosphate" provides an answer to the problem of scale forming on boiler tubes. The chemical is named "Calgon," meaning "calcium gone."

event.name: George Merck buys back the stock of Merck & Co.
event.shortDescription: George Merck buys back the stock of Merck & Co.
event.fullDescription:
1919
George Merck buys back his own company and Merck & Co. fully separates from E. Merck.

event.name: T. L. Williams copyrights the name Maybelline
event.shortDescription: T. L. Williams copyrights the name Maybelline for his cosmetics company.
event.fullDescription: T. L. Williams copyrights the name Maybelline for his cosmetics company, named in honor of his sister Mabel.

event.name: Merck organizes a fire squad
event.shortDescription: Merck organizes a fire squad.
event.fullDescription:
1920
Merck purchases its first fire engine and forms a volunteer fire squad.

event.name: Plough Chemical Company acquires the St. Joseph brand name
event.shortDescription: Plough Chemical Company acquires the Gerstle Chemical Company and the St. Joseph brand name
event.fullDescription:
1921
Plough Chemical Company purchases The Gerstle Medicine Company of Chattanooga, Tenn., acquiring the trade name St. Joseph, an established brand name in the family medicine field for over 50 years.

event.name: Plough Chemical Company begins selling stock to the public
event.shortDescription: Plough Chemical Company begins selling stock to the public.
event.fullDescription:
1923
Plough Chemical Company begins selling stock to the public.

event.name: H. K. Mulford Co. rushes serum to treat bubonic plague outbreak
event.shortDescription: H. K. Mulford Co. rushes Yersin Serum to Los Angeles to treat an outbreak of bubonic plague.
event.fullDescription: 6,500 doses of H.K. Mulford's Yersin Serum are rushed from its Philadelphia laboratories to Los Angeles, Calif., to treat a deadly outbreak of the bubonic plague.

event.name: George W. Merck becomes president of Merck & Co.
event.shortDescription: George W. Merck succeeds his father as president of Merck & Co.
event.fullDescription: George Merck becomes Chairman of the Board and his son, George W. Merck, succeeds him as president of Merck & Co.

event.name: H. K. Mulford introduces dried vaccine
event.shortDescription: H. K. Mulford introduces dried vaccine.
event.fullDescription:
H. K. Mulford introduces a dried vaccine for use in tropical countries.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: H. K. Mulford Co. rushes diphtheria antitoxin by dogsled to Nome, Alaska
event.shortDescription: H. K. Mulford Co. rushes diphtheria antitoxin by dogsled to treat an outbreak in Nome, Alaska.
event.fullDescription:
An outbreak of diphtheria occurs in Nome, Alaska. H.K. Mulford's diphtheria antitoxin is rushed by dogsled from Nenana, Alaska, to Nome. The trip is 674 miles long and takes five days and twenty drivers and dog teams to complete. The trip is considered to be part of the inspiration for the annual Iditarod Trail Dog Sled Race.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Merck & Co. transfers main offices to Rahway, N.J.
event.shortDescription: Merck & Co. transfers main offices to Rahway, N.J.
event.fullDescription:
1926
Merck & Co. transfers its main offices from Manhattan, N.Y. to the Rahway, N.J. site.

event.name: Powers-Weightman-Rosengarten and Merck & Co. consolidate to form Merck & Co., Inc.
event.shortDescription: Powers-Weightman-Rosengarten and Merck & Co. consolidate to form Merck & Co., Inc.
event.fullDescription:
1927
Merck & Co. merges with Powers-Weightman-Rosengarten.

event.name: Schering Corporation is established
event.shortDescription:
1928
Schering Corporation, a U.S. subsidiary of Schering AG, is established.
event.fullDescription: Julius Weltzien, director of Schering AG's international expansion, creates a new U.S. subsidiary – Schering Corporation.

event.name: Sharp & Dohme introduces SUCRETS
event.shortDescription: Sharp & Dohme introduces the throat lozenges SUCRETS.
event.fullDescription:
1929
Sharp & Dohme introduces an antiseptic throat lozenge marketed under the trade name SUCRETS.

event.name: H. K. Mulford Co. merges with Sharp & Dohme
event.shortDescription: H. K. Mulford Co. merges with Sharp & Dohme.
event.fullDescription: H. K. Mulford Co. merges with Sharp & Dohme, Inc.

event.name: Plough Chemical Company becomes Plough, Inc.
event.shortDescription: Plough Chemical Company becomes Plough, Inc.
event.fullDescription: The Plough Chemical Company changes its name to Plough, Inc.

event.name: Merck opens new research laboratories in Rahway, N.J.
event.shortDescription: Merck opens new, expanded research facilities that consolidate operations into one building.
event.fullDescription:
1933
Merck dedicates modern and expanded research laboratories in Rahway, N.J. The laboratories, including the Merck Institute for Therapeutic Research, are now all consolidated into one building. George W. Merck, whose leadership was instrumental in establishing Merck's research organization, announces at the dedication ceremony, "We have the faith that in this new laboratory, with the tools we have supplied, science will be advanced, knowledge increased, and human life will win ever a greater freedom from suffering and disease."

event.name: Merck exhibits at the Century of Progress International Exposition
event.shortDescription: Merck exhibits at the Century of Progress International Exposition.
event.fullDescription:
1933
Merck sponsors an exhibit at the Century of Progress International Exposition in Chicago, Ill.

event.name: Plough, Inc. lists its shares on the New York Curb Exchange
event.shortDescription: Plough, Inc. lists its shares on the New York Curb Exchange
event.fullDescription: Plough, Inc. lists its shares on the New York Curb Exchange, which is now known as the New York Stock Exchange

event.name: Chemists from Merck and Bell Labs synthesize vitamin B1
event.shortDescription: Chemists from Merck and Bell Labs synthesize vitamin B1, paving the way for major vitamin research at Merck.
event.fullDescription:
1936
Merck chemist J. K. Cline, together with Dr. Robert Williams of Bell Labs, develops the first synthesis of vitamin B1. Within a few years, the product sharply reduces vitamin B1 deficiency (beriberi) and constitutes more than ten percent of Merck's sales.

event.name: Merck publishes "Treatment of War Injuries"
event.shortDescription: Merck publishes a "Treatment of War Injuries"
event.fullDescription:
1941
Merck publishes a "Treatment of War Injuries" booklet for civilian and military physicians who may be confronted with the duty of providing medical treatment.

event.name: Merck's Stonewall plant begins manufacturing operations
event.shortDescription: Merck's Stonewall plant opens in Elkton, Virginia, and begins manufacturing vitamins B1 and B2.
event.fullDescription:
1941
"Vitamin Valley" is born. The Stonewall manufacturing site begins production in December, providing new employment opportunities to residents of the Shenandoah Valley in Depression-era Virginia. The plant, employing about 300 people, first produces vitamins B1 and B2 and pantothenic acid. Stonewall steadily adds new products and more complex processes, including manufacturing for two products, penicillin and streptomycin.

event.name: Sharp & Dohme supplies dried blood plasma to the armed forces throughout WWII
event.shortDescription: Sharp & Dohme helps save thousands of lives during WWII by producing dried blood plasma
event.fullDescription:
1941
Sharp & Dohme's major contribution to WWII is dried blood plasma. During the first nine months of the war, Sharp & Dohme is the only company prepared to supply dried plasma to the armed forces. Military and medical authorities agree that the development of dried plasma saved thousands of men's lives and was one of the outstanding medical contributions to the war effort.

event.name: Merck begins producing penicillin "G"
event.shortDescription: Merck begins producing penicillin "G" at the request of the U.S. government
event.fullDescription:
1942
At the request of the U.S. government, Merck begins producing penicillin "G." One of the first vials is shipped to New Haven, Conn., and used to treat a young woman named Anne Miller. This marks the first successful penicillin treatment of a blood infection in the U.S.

event.name: Merck develops submerged fermentation process for producing penicillin
event.shortDescription: Merck researchers develop a submerged fermentation process to speed the production of penicillin.
event.fullDescription:
1942
In cooperation with competitors to produce needed drugs for both the war effort and civilian use, the Merck research team helped develop a submerged fermentation process that speeded production of penicillin. Merck's penicillin manufacturing begins full operation, turning out 4.18 billion units of penicillin, the first successful antibiotic.

event.name: Merck wins its first Army-Navy "E" Award
event.shortDescription: Merck wins the first of many Army-Navy "E" Awards for production that it will receive for wartime production.
event.fullDescription:
1943
Merck wins its first Army-Navy Production Award, or "E" award, for wartime production. The coveted "E" flags were on display at Rahway, N.J., Elkton, Va., and Philadelphia, Pa. plants. Both Merck & Co. and Sharp & Dohme win numerous "E" awards throughout the war.

event.name: Merck makes its first donation to the United Negro College Fund
event.shortDescription: Merck makes its first donation to the United Negro College Fund.
event.fullDescription: Merck makes its first donation to the United Negro College Fund, launching a long-standing partnership.

event.name: Dr. Selman Waksman and Albert Schatz discover streptomycin
event.shortDescription: Dr. Selman Waksman and Albert Schatz discover streptomycin and Merck turns over exclusive patent rights to the drug at Waksman's request.
event.fullDescription:
1944
Dr. Selman Waksman of Rutgers University and his colleague Albert Schatz discover streptomycin. Waksman received support from Merck's chemists, use of the testing facilities at the Merck Institute, and assurance that pilot plant facilities would be available for producing substances. In exchange, Merck received patent rights to any processes Dr. Waksman developed. Dr. Waksman, concerned that he had "turned over valuable public-health processes to a single organization for commercial exploitation," asked Merck to abandon these valuable patent rights. Looking beyond issues of short term profitability, George W. Merck turned over the patents to a Rutgers foundation, which licensed all applicants to produce the drug.

event.name: Dr. Lewis Sarett synthesizes cortisone
event.shortDescription: Dr. Lewis Sarett synthesizes cortisone.
event.fullDescription:
1944
After two years of intensive research, Merck chemist Dr. Lewis Sarett synthesizes cortisone, however, not in quantities sufficient for testing. Dr. Max Tishler, aided by Dr. Jacob van de Kamp, spends the next two years solving the developmental puzzles of cortisone manufacturing, and in 1948 with cortisone in pilot plant production, they were able to make amounts sufficient for the tests that established the drug as the first breakthrough in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

event.name: Plough, Inc. purchases radio station
event.shortDescription: Plough, Inc. purchases a radio station in Memphis, Tenn.
event.fullDescription:
1944
Plough, Inc. enters the broadcasting field with the purchase of radio station WMPS, Memphis, Tenn.

event.name: Benjamin Green debuts COPPERTONE
event.shortDescription: Benjamin Green debuts COPPERTONE Suntan Cream.
event.fullDescription:
1944
Benjamin Green debuts his COPPERTONE Suntan Cream product, a mixture he created by cooking cocoa butter in a granite coffee pot on his wife's stove and testing each batch on his own bald head. He was bought out in 1950 by three investors who set up Douglas Laboratories Corporation and later establish a sales force, incorporating it under the name The COPPERTONE Sales Corporation.

event.name: Plough, Inc. introduces ST. JOSEPH ASPIRIN FOR CHILDREN
event.shortDescription: Plough, Inc. introduces ST. JOSEPH ASPIRIN FOR CHILDREN.
event.fullDescription:
1947
Plough, Inc. introduces ST. JOSEPH ASPIRIN FOR CHILDREN.

event.name: Schering Corporation introduces TRIMETON
event.shortDescription: Schering Corporation introduces its antihistamine, TRIMETON.
event.fullDescription:
1948
Schering Corporation's antihistamine, TRIMETON — the result of an experiment to produce an analgesic gone wrong — is launched and is the predecessor of CHLOR-TRIMETON. CHLOR-TRIMETON is launched in 1949.

event.name: Merck introduces S.Q.
event.shortDescription: Merck introduces the animal health product S.Q.
event.fullDescription:
1949
After five years of extensive testing, Merck brings S.Q. (sulfaquinoxaline) to market. The product, used to prevent coccidiosis, a poultry disease, ushers Merck into the animal health field.

event.name: Sharp & Dohme acquires plant site in West Point, Pa.
event.shortDescription: Sharp & Dohme acquires plant site in West Point, Pa.
event.fullDescription:
1948
Sharp & Dohme purchases a plant in West Point, Pa., where it centralizes its operations previously conducted at Ridgeway, Glenolden, and Philadelphia, Pa.

event.name: Vitamin B12 is introduced as a treatment for pernicious anemia
event.shortDescription: Vitamin B12 is introduced as a treatment for pernicious anemia.
event.fullDescription:
1949
Vitamin B12 is introduced as a treatment for pernicious anemia. Merck researcher Karl Folkers and team isolated Vitamin B12 after nearly nine years of research.

event.name: James J. Kerrigan is named president of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.shortDescription: James J. Kerrigan succeeds George W. Merck as president of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.fullDescription:
1950
James J. Kerrigan succeeds George W. Merck as president of Merck & Co.

event.name: As a result of his collaboration with Merck, Dr. Edward C. Kendall of the Mayo Clinic is awarded a Nobel prize
event.shortDescription: As a result of his collaboration with Merck, Dr. Edward C. Kendall receives a Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
event.fullDescription:
1950
The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded jointly to Dr. Edward C. Kendall, Tadeus Reichstein and Philip Showalter Hench for their discoveries relating to hormones of the adrenal cortex, their structure and biological effects. Dr. Kendall, of the Mayo Clinic, and Merck's Dr. Lewis Sarett began collaborating on the cortisone synthesis process in 1941, and in 1948 – led by Merck's Dr. Max Tishler and Dr. Jacob van de Kamp -- the first large scale synthesis of Compound E (cortisone) was completed at Merck.

event.name: George W. Merck makes his well-known "medicine is for the people" speech
event.shortDescription: George W. Merck makes his well-known "medicine is for the people, it is not for the profits" speech at the Medical College of Virginia.
event.fullDescription: George W. Merck gives a talk at the Medical College of Virginia at Richmond during which he makes the well-known statement: "We must try to remember that medicine is for the patient. We try never to forget that medicine is for the people. It is not for the profits. The profits follow, and if we have remembered that, they have never failed to appear. The better we have remembered it, the larger they have been."

event.name: George W. Merck appears on the cover of TIME magazine
event.shortDescription: George W. Merck appears on the cover of TIME magazine.
event.fullDescription:
1952
The cover story of TIME, "What the Doctor Ordered," profiles Merck's history, its business and George W. Merck.

event.name: Dr. Selman Waksman is awarded a Nobel prize
event.shortDescription: Dr. Selman Waksman receives a Nobel Prize for the discovery of Streptomycin
event.fullDescription:
1952
Dr. Selman Waksman, a researcher at Rutgers University, receives the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his discovery of Streptomycin. The drug was developed with the support of the Merck Institute for Therapeutic Research through a formal agreement created in 1939.

event.name: Merck merges with Sharp & Dohme
event.shortDescription: Merck merges with the Philadelphia-based pharmaceutical company, Sharp & Dohme, Inc.
event.fullDescription:
1953
Merck merges with Philadelphia-based Sharp & Dohme. The combined company now has a larger sales and distribution network to complement the research labs of both organizations. Subsequently, management creates an entirely new entity, Merck Sharp & Dohme International (MSDI), to market the company's pharmaceuticals around the world.

event.name: Little Miss Coppertone makes her debut
event.shortDescription: Little Miss Coppertone makes her debut, advertising the COPPERTONE brand of suncare products.
event.fullDescription:
1954
Little Miss Coppertone, the Coppertone icon, makes her debut, advertising the COPPERTONE brand of suncare products.

event.name: Merck introduces COGENTIN (benztropine mesylate)
event.shortDescription: Merck introduces COGENTIN (benztropine mesylate).
event.fullDescription: Merck introduces COGENTIN (benztropine mesylate).

event.name: John T. Connor is named president and CEO of Merck & Co.
event.shortDescription: John T. Connor is named president and CEO, succeeding James J. Kerrigan.
event.fullDescription:
1955
John T. Connor is named president and CEO of Merck & Co., succeeding James J. Kerrigan.

event.name: The first edition of the Merck Veterinary Manual is published
event.shortDescription: The first edition of the Merck Veterinary Manual is published.
event.fullDescription: The first edition of the Merck Veterinary Manual is published.

event.name: Dr. Maurice Hilleman joins Merck
event.shortDescription: Dr. Maurice Hilleman joins the Merck Institute for Therapeutic Research.
event.fullDescription:
1956
Dr. Maurice Hilleman joins Merck as the director of Virus and Cell Biology Research at the Merck Institute for Therapeutic Research in West Point, Pa.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Plough, Inc. acquires The Coppertone Corporation
event.shortDescription: Plough, Inc. acquires The Coppertone Corporation.
event.fullDescription:
1957
Plough, Inc. acquires The Coppertone Corporation, a recognized leader in the field of suntan products.

event.name: Plough, Inc. introduces the first safety cap for children's products
event.shortDescription: Plough, Inc. introduces the first safety cap for children's products.
event.fullDescription: Plough, Inc. introduces the first safety cap for children's products, 12 years before legislation is passed requiring drug companies to do so. The cap was developed by Abe Plough due to concerns that the orange flavored St. Joseph Children's Aspirin might increase accidental ingestions.

event.name: Kelco begins research of xanthan gum
event.shortDescription: Kelco begins research of xanthan gum.
event.fullDescription: Kelco Company pursues development of a promising new biogum (later named xanthan gum), a water-controlling agent used in a wide range of consumer and industrial products including pharmaceuticals.

event.name: Plough, Inc. acquires three new companies
event.shortDescription: Plough, Inc. acquires PAAS, Southern Shellac and WPLO, Atlanta, Ga.
event.fullDescription:
1959
Plough, Inc. acquires the PAAS Company, the largest manufacturer of Easter egg colors and kits; the Southern Shellac Company, the largest producer of liquid shellac in the U.S.; and radio station WPLO, Atlanta, Ga.

event.name: The George W. Merck Loan Fund is established
event.shortDescription: The George W. Merck Loan Fund for medical interns and residents is established.
event.fullDescription:
1959
The Merck Company Foundation establishes a $400,000 George W. Merck Loan Fund to assist medical interns and residents seeking postgraduate training in teaching hospitals before entering practice. The program intends to help 60 to 100 young doctors annually from 18 different medical schools.

event.name: Plough, Inc. acquires two household products brands
event.shortDescription: Plough, Inc. acquires The Webb Products Company and Dicks-Armstrong-Pontius, both household products brands.
event.fullDescription:
1960
Plough, Inc. acquires The Webb Products Companies of San Bernardino, Calif., and Norcross, Ga. Its nationally famous line of "do-it-yourself" household products are sold under the "Duratite" label and include Duratite Wood Dough and Surfacing Putty, the second largest selling products of their type in the country. Later that year, Plough, Inc. acquires Dicks-Armstrong-Pontius, Inc., a manufacturer of household products.

event.name: The SPAFAS company is established
event.shortDescription: The SPAFAS, specific pathogen-free avian supplies, company is founded in Norwich, Conn.
event.fullDescription:
1961
SPAFAS, an acronym for "specific pathogen-free avian supplies," is started in Norwich, Conn., by Raymond Davis and Dr. Roy Luginbuhl. The company develops and produces specific pathogen-free fertile eggs for medical research and vaccine production.

event.name: Plough Laboratories, Inc. is formed
event.shortDescription: Plough, Inc. forms a pharmaceutical division, Plough Laboratories, Inc.
event.fullDescription: Plough, Inc. forms Plough Laboratories, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary operating separately from the parent company as a pharmaceutical division in the prescription drug field.

event.name: The Pimpri, India manufacturing facility opens
event.shortDescription: Merck works with government of India to open a manufacturing plant in Pimpri.
event.fullDescription:
1962
Merck works with the government of India to open a manufacturing facility in Pimpri, India.

event.name: Merck introduces RUBEOVAX (Measles Virus Vaccine, Live, Attenuated)
event.shortDescription: Merck introduces RUBEOVAX (Measles Virus Vaccine, Live, Attenuated).
event.fullDescription:
1963
Merck introduces RUBEOVAX (Measles Virus Vaccine, Live, Attenuated).

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Henry W. Gadsden is named president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.shortDescription: Henry W. Gadsden succeeds John T. Connor as president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.fullDescription:
1965
Henry W. Gadsden succeeds John T. Connor as president and CEO of Merck & Co, Inc.

event.name: Plough, Inc. acquires Maybelline cosmetics
event.shortDescription: Plough, Inc. acquires Maybelline cosmetics.
event.fullDescription:
1967
Plough, Inc. acquires Maybelline cosmetics.

event.name: Merck introduces MUMPSVAX (Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live)
event.shortDescription: Merck introduces MUMPSVAX (Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live) developed by Dr. Maurice Hilleman
event.fullDescription:
Merck introduces MUMPSVAX (Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live) developed by Dr. Maurice Hilleman with a culture from the throat of his young daughter, Jeryl Lynn.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Merck & Co., Inc. acquires Calgon Corporation
event.shortDescription: Merck & Co., Inc. acquires the water treatment chemicals and services company Calgon Corporation.
event.fullDescription:
1968
Merck & Co., Inc. acquires Calgon Corporation, one of the nation's leading suppliers of water treatment chemicals and services.

event.name: Merck introduces MERUVAX II  (Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live)
event.shortDescription: Merck introduces MERUVAX II  (Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live).
event.fullDescription:
1969
After nine years of research, Merck introduces MERUVAX II  (Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live).

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Merck & Co, Inc. acquires Chibret Laboratories
event.shortDescription: Merck & Co, Inc. acquires Chibret Laboratories.
event.fullDescription:
1969
Chibret Laboratories, a major France-based manufacturer of ophthalmic products, is acquired by Merck.

event.name: Schering Corporation and Plough, Inc. merge
event.shortDescription: Schering Corporation merges with consumer products company Plough, Inc.
event.fullDescription:
1971
Schering Corporation and Plough, Inc. merge to form Schering-Plough Corporation. Abe Plough is made Chairman of the Board.

event.name: Merck introduces M-M-R II (Measles, Mumps and Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live)
event.shortDescription: Merck introduces M-M-R II (Measles, Mumps and Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live).
event.fullDescription:
Merck introduces M-M-R II (Measles, Mumps and Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live).

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Merck introduces DEPTAVAC-HVT (Marek's disease vaccine)
event.shortDescription: Merck introduces DEPTAVAC-HVT (Marek's disease vaccine) for poultry.
event.fullDescription:
Maurice Hilleman introduces veterinary DEPTAVAC-HVT (Marek's disease vaccine).

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: The Calgon Consumer Products Company Inc. is established
event.shortDescription: Calgon Consumer Products Company Inc. is established as the consumer products division of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.fullDescription: The Consumer Products Division is established as a separate subsidiary of Merck and renamed the Calgon Consumer Products Company Inc. The new company is responsible for the development, marketing and sales of all Calgon and Merck brands of consumer products and non-prescription drugs. Robert A. Fallon is named president.

event.name: Merck totals more than 1 billion dollars in sales this year
event.shortDescription: Merck's annual sales and total number of employees reach record numbers.
event.fullDescription: Merck has its first billion-dollar year in sales, while total number of employees reaches 25,000 for the first time.

event.name: Merck scientists produce the first analyzable sample of a broad-spectrum antibiotic
event.shortDescription: Merck scientists produce the first analyzable sample of a broad-spectrum antibiotic.
event.fullDescription:
1974
Research teams under the leadership of Fred and Jean Kahan produce the first analyzable sample of a broad-spectrum antibiotic.

event.name: COPPERTONE Solar Research Center helps determine the Sun Protection Factors
event.shortDescription: COPPERTONE Solar Research Center helps determine the Sun Protection Factors.
event.fullDescription:
1974-1976
COPPERTONE Solar Research Center works with the Food and Drug Administration to determine the Sun Protection Factors (SPF).

event.name: Merck gains FDA approval of drug for SINEMET (levodopa and carbidopa)
event.shortDescription: Merck gains FDA approval of SINEMET (levodopa and carbidopa).
event.fullDescription:
1975
After 15 years of research, Merck gains FDA approval of SINEMET (levodopa and carbidopa).

event.name: John J. Horan becomes president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.shortDescription: John J. Horan succeeds Henry Gadsden as president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.fullDescription:
1976
John J. Horan succeeds Henry Gadsden as president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.

event.name: Richard J. Bennet becomes CEO of Schering-Plough Corporation
event.shortDescription: Richard J. Bennet becomes CEO of Schering-Plough Corporation.
event.fullDescription:
1978
Richard J. Bennet becomes CEO of Schering-Plough Corporation.

event.name: Merck introduces PNEUMOVAX (pneumococcal vaccine polyvalent)
event.shortDescription:
1978
Merck introduces PNEUMOVAX (pneumococcal vaccine polyvalent).
event.fullDescription:
Merck introduces PNEUMOVAX (pneumococcal vaccine polyvalent).

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Schering-Plough acquires Scholl, Inc.
event.shortDescription: Schering-Plough acquires the foot care firm Scholl, Inc.
event.fullDescription:
1979
Schering-Plough acquires Scholl, Inc., the 74-year-old Chicago, Ill., foot care firm.

event.name: Schering-Plough invests in biotechnology research
event.shortDescription: Schering-Plough invests $8 million in the biotech startup Biogen.
event.fullDescription:
1982
Robert Luciano, then senior vice president and future CEO of Schering-Plough, convinces the company's current CEO to invest $8 million in the small startup biotech company Biogen.

event.name: Merck develops one of the first ever company-wide diversity training programs
event.shortDescription: Merck develops one of the first ever company-wide diversity training programs.
event.fullDescription:
1980
Merck is one of the first companies to develop an affirmative action training program and to deliver it to all employees, from senior executives to shop floor workers. Subsequently 125 major U.S. corporations license the program.

event.name: Robert P. Luciano becomes CEO of Schering-Plough Corporation
event.shortDescription: Robert P. Luciano becomes CEO of Schering-Plough Corporation.
event.fullDescription: Robert P. Luciano becomes CEO of Schering-Plough Corporation and leads the company into the field of biotechnology.

event.name: Schering-Plough donates 50,000 rock and roll records and tapes to Memphis, Tenn., colleges and universities
event.shortDescription: Schering-Plough donates 50,000 rock and roll records and tapes to Memphis, Tenn., colleges and universities.
event.fullDescription: Schering-Plough donates approximately 50,000 records and tape recordings of original releases by Memphis, Tenn., recording artists such as Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis and Isaac Hayes to three Memphis colleges and universities. The collection comes from some of the 12 stations formerly owned by Plough Broadcasting.

event.name: Dr. P. Roy Vagelos is named president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.shortDescription: Dr. P. Roy Vagelos is named president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.fullDescription:
1985
Dr. P. Roy Vagelos is named president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.

event.name: Working Mother magazine names Merck one of the top five companies in its annual "Best Companies" list
event.shortDescription: Working Mother magazine names Merck one of the top five companies in its annual "Best Companies" list
event.fullDescription: Working Mother magazine inaugurated its "best companies" list in the mid-1980s. Merck has been named to the list consistently since then.

event.name: Merck introduces new genetically engineered vaccine for humans
event.shortDescription: Merck introduces a new genetically engineered vaccine approved for use in humans.
event.fullDescription:
A research team led by Dr. Edward M. Scolnick introduces a new genetically engineered vaccine for humans. It is made from recombinant DNA instead of blood plasma.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Merck commits to donate MECTIZAN
event.shortDescription: Merck commits to donate MECTIZAN — as much as needed for as long as needed — with the goal to help eliminate river blindness.
event.fullDescription:
1987
Merck CEO Dr. Roy Vagelos announces Merck's commitment to donate MECTIZAN – as much as needed for as long as needed -- with the goal to help eliminate river blindness. In order to reach this goal, Merck leaders recognize that many organizations with unique skills will need to work together as a team. Thus, the Mectizan Donation Program (MDP) is created as a ground-breaking public-private partnership that becomes influential in the development of a number of other drug donation programs.

event.name: Merck introduces the first of the statin family of medicines
event.shortDescription: Merck introduces the first of the statin family of medicines.
event.fullDescription: Merck's introduces the first of the statin family of medicines to be approved by the FDA. It emerges from 35 years of study by scientists in the U.S. and abroad, at universities, independent laboratories and at Merck.

event.name: Merck is named America's most admired and most innovative company
event.shortDescription: Merck is named America's most admired company by Fortune magazine and most innovative company by Forbes magazine.
event.fullDescription:
1987
For the first of seven consecutive years, Fortune magazine names Merck America's most admired corporation. And, in its annual industry survey, Forbes magazine names Merck the most innovative company in the pharmaceutical industry.

event.name: Johnson & Johnson Merck Consumer Pharmaceuticals Co. is established
event.shortDescription: Johnson & Johnson Merck Consumer Pharmaceuticals Co. is established in the over-the-counter healthcare business.
event.fullDescription: The formation of Johnson & Johnson Merck Consumer Pharmaceuticals Co. establishes Merck's presence in the over-the-counter (OTC) healthcare business.

event.name: The Children's Inn opens at the National Institutes of Health (NIH)
event.shortDescription: The Children's Inn opens as a residence for children being treated at the National Institutes of Health and their families.
event.fullDescription:
1989
The Children's Inn, a residence for pediatric patients and their families on the campus of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., opens its doors. The guest house, built with a $3.7 million grant from Merck, allows children and their families to live in a homelike environment while the children receive innovative treatments at the NIH facilities.

event.name: Merck publishes The Merck Manual of Geriatrics
event.shortDescription: Merck publishes the first edition of The Merck Manual of Geriatrics.
event.fullDescription:
1990
In response to a growing elderly population, Merck publishes The Merck Manual of Geriatrics.

event.name: Merck & Co., Inc. celebrates its 100-year anniversary
event.shortDescription: Merck & Co., Inc. celebrates its 100-year anniversary.
event.fullDescription:
1991
Merck celebrates its 100th anniversary.

event.name: The FDA approves ZOCOR (simvastatin)
event.shortDescription: The FDA approves ZOCOR (simvastatin).
event.fullDescription: The FDA approves ZOCOR (simvastatin) for use in the U.S.

event.name: Merck amends its EEO policy to include sexual orientation
event.shortDescription: Merck amends its EEO policy to include sexual orientation.
event.fullDescription:
Merck demonstrates a commitment to lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender equal rights by voluntarily amending its corporate Equal Employment Opportunity policy to include sexual orientation.

In 2002, Merck participates in the first Human Rights Campaign Corporate Equality Index, which assesses lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender equality at workplaces in the U.S. In 2006 Merck achieves a 100% score in the Index.

event.name: Merck & Co., Inc. acquires Medco Containment Services, Inc.
event.shortDescription: Merck & Co., Inc. acquires Medco Containment Services, Inc. to create America's first coordinated pharmaceutical care company.
event.fullDescription: Merck acquires Medco Containment Services, Inc. to create America's first coordinated pharmaceutical care company.

event.name: Raymond V. Gilmartin becomes president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.shortDescription: Raymond V. Gilmartin succeeds P. Roy Vagelos as president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.fullDescription:
1994
Merck announces that Raymond V. Gilmartin will succeed retiring Dr. Roy Vagelos as Merck president and CEO, becoming the first outsider to hold either position in the company's 103-year history.

event.name: Schering-Plough promotes the new Ultraviolet Index
event.shortDescription: Schering-Plough promotes the National Weather Service's new Ultraviolet Index.
event.fullDescription: Schering-Plough teams with a coalition of medical, environmental, consumer and public health groups to promote the National Weather Service's new Ultraviolet (UV) Index. The UV Index will provide daily readings of the UV risk levels as part of local forecasts in 58 cities.

event.name: A World Bank program to expand distribution of MECTIZAN is announced
event.shortDescription: A World Bank program to expand distribution of MECTIZAN is announced.
event.fullDescription:
1994
Retired Merck Chairman Dr. Roy Vagelos and former U.S. President Jimmy Carter announce a new World Bank grant program to expand distribution of MECTIZAN through the Mectizan Donation Program for the treatment of river blindness.

event.name: FOSAMAX (alendronate sodium) is approved by the FDA
event.shortDescription: FOSAMAX (alendronate sodium) is approved by the FDA.
event.fullDescription: The FDA approves FOSAMAX (alendronate sodium).

event.name: Merck and Washington University release the first human gene sequences identified in the Merck Gene Index.
event.shortDescription: Merck and Washington University release the first human gene sequences identified in their collaborative project, the Merck Gene Index
event.fullDescription: Merck and Washington University announce the public release of the first 15,000 expressed human gene sequences from their collaborative effort to identify cDNA clones for expressed human genes.

event.name: Merck announces the CRIXIVAN Program
event.shortDescription: Merck announces the CRIXIVAN Program while the drug is still in Phase III clinical trials.
event.fullDescription: In conjunction with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, patients and advocacy groups, Merck decides to offer the Crixivan Program. Through this program, Merck will make the drug available at no cost to selected patients before it is commercially available. CRIXIVAN is in Phase III of clinical trials at the time.

event.name: Merck unveils A Gift of Sight statue at world headquarters in Whitehouse Station, N.J.
event.shortDescription: Merck unveils a seven-foot bronze statue, A Gift of Sight, at its world headquarters in Whitehouse Station, N.J.
event.fullDescription:
1995
Merck unveils a seven-foot bronze statue, A Gift of Sight, at its world headquarters in Whitehouse Station, N.J. Created by R.T. Wallen of Alaska, the statue portrays a young African boy leading a blind man and has come to symbolize the fight to eliminate river blindness.

event.name: The World Bank launches the African Program for Onchocerciasis
event.shortDescription: The World Bank launches a twelve-year program to control river blindness is Africa.
event.fullDescription:
1995
The World Bank launches the African Program for Onchocerciasis Control (APOC), a new twelve-year program to control river blindness in Africa using Merck's donation of Mectizan.

event.name: Merck and UNCF team up to create the UNCF/Merck Science Initiative
event.shortDescription: Merck and UNCF team up to create the UNCF/Merck Science Initiative.
event.fullDescription:
1995
Merck and UNCF (United Negro College Fund) team up to create the UNCF/Merck Science Initiative to help young African-American scientists and researchers achieve their full potential. Established with a $20 million pledge from The Merck Company Foundation, the initiative provides financial support, hands-on training and mentoring.

event.name: Richard J. Kogan becomes CEO of Schering-Plough Corporation
event.shortDescription: Richard J. Kogan becomes CEO of Schering-Plough Corporation.
event.fullDescription:
1996
Richard J. Kogan becomes CEO of Schering-Plough Corporation.

event.name: Merck opens laboratory devoted to human genetics
event.shortDescription: Merck opens a laboratory devoted to human genetics at its West Point, Pa. facility.
event.fullDescription: Merck opens a new laboratory devoted to human genetics at its West Point, Pa., facility. The company also expands its genomics research and gene therapy projects by recruiting leading researchers.

event.name: CRIXIVAN (INDINAVIR SULFATE) is approved by the FDA
event.shortDescription: CRIXIVAN (INDINAVIR SULFATE) is approved by the FDA after a review period of 42 days.
event.fullDescription: CRIXIVAN (INDINAVIR SULFATE) is approved by the FDA after a review period of 42 days.

event.name: Dr. Maurice Hilleman receives a Children's Vaccine Initiative Lifetime Achievement Award
event.shortDescription: Dr. Maurice Hilleman receives a Lifetime Achievement Award from The Children's Vaccine Initiative of the World Health Organization.
event.fullDescription:
1996
The Children's Vaccine Initiative of the World Health Organization grants its Lifetime Achievement Award to Dr. Maurice Hilleman, director of the Merck Institute for Therapeutic Research.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Merck forms the Merck Genome Research Institute
event.shortDescription: Merck forms the Merck Genome Research Institute to research human genetic information.
event.fullDescription: Merck launches the Merck Genome Research Institute, Inc. to develop scientific technology that leads to linking human genetic traits and resolving the biological function of disease genes. The initiative provides additional support to the Merck Gene Index project, a public database of gene sequences launched in 1994 that gives scientists worldwide unrestricted access to gene sequences and their cDNA clones.

event.name: Dr. Maurice Hilleman is awarded the Albert B. Sabin Gold Medal Award
event.shortDescription: Dr. Maurice Hilleman is awarded the Sabin Gold Medal Award by the Albert B. Sabin Foundation.
event.fullDescription:
1997
The Albert B. Sabin Foundation awards Dr. Maurice Hilleman, director of the Merck Institute for Therapeutic Research, the Sabin Gold Medal Award. Dr. Hilleman is credited with developing more vaccines than any other person in history and pioneering the development of numerous live, killed and combination vaccines.

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: The Merck Manual - Home Edition is first published
event.shortDescription: The Merck Manual - Home Edition is first published.
event.fullDescription:
1997
The Merck Manual of Medical Information - Home Edition is first published. Based on the Merck Manual, the world's best-selling medical reference book, The Home Edition is designed for consumers in easy-to-understand language. The first edition sells more than two million copies.

event.name: Merck and Rhone-Poulenc combine to form Merial, the world's largest animal health and poultry genetics company
event.shortDescription: Merck and Rhone-Poulenc combine to form Merial, the world's largest animal health and poultry genetics company.
event.fullDescription: Merck and Rhone-Poulenc combine their animal health and poultry genetics businesses to form the stand-alone, joint venture Merial. Merial becomes the world's largest company dedicated to the discovery, manufacture and marketing of veterinary pharmaceuticals and vaccines.

event.name: Merck helps form the African Comprehensive HIV/AIDS Partnerships
event.shortDescription: Merck joins with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the Republic of Botswana to form the African Comprehensive HIV/AIDS Partnerships.
event.fullDescription:
1999
Merck joins with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the Republic of Botswana to form the African Comprehensive HIV/AIDS Partnerships (ACHAP). Merck and the Gates Foundation each commit $56.5 million to help Botswana implement a national HIV and AIDS strategy, with Merck also donating medicines.

event.name: Merck announces plans to make Merck-Medco a separate company
event.shortDescription: Merck announces plans to make Merck-Medco a separate company.
event.fullDescription: Merck announces plans to make Merck-Medco, a pharmacy benefits management subsidiary, a separate, publicly-traded company.

event.name: Fred Hassan becomes CEO of Schering-Plough
event.shortDescription: Fred Hassan becomes CEO of Schering-Plough.
event.fullDescription:
2003
Fred Hassan becomes CEO of Schering-Plough.

event.name: Banyu Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd. becomes a subsidiary of Merck
event.shortDescription: Banyu Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd. becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of Merck.
event.fullDescription: Building on a 50-year relationship, Banyu Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd. becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of Merck. Banyu is Merck's largest wholly owned subsidiary outside the U.S. and now extends the company's network of wholly owned operations to every major market in the world.

event.name: Merck establishes the Merck Childhood Asthma Network
event.shortDescription: Merck establishes the Merck Childhood Asthma Network.
event.fullDescription:
2005
Merck announces the creation of the Merck Childhood Asthma Network (MCAN), a separately incorporated non-profit organization based in Washington, D.C., that will address the complex and persistent problem of asthma among children in the U.S. The Merck Company Foundation pledges to support the initiative with a commitment of up to $20 million over a four year period.

event.name: Merck launches the Merck Prescription Discount Program
event.shortDescription: Merck launches the Merck Prescription Discount Program to help eligible uninsured Americans get the Merck medicines they need.
event.fullDescription: Merck launches the Merck Prescription Discount Program, a comprehensive prescription drug discount program designed to help eligible patients without drug coverage in the U.S.

event.name: Richard T. Clark named CEO and president of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.shortDescription: Richard T. Clark succeeds Raymond V. Gilmartin as CEO and president of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.fullDescription:
2005
Richard T. Clark succeeds Raymond V. Gilmartin as president and CEO of Merck & Co., Inc. Mr. Clark was most recently president of the Merck Manufacturing Division.

event.name: Merck establishes the Comprehensive HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control Cooperative Project
event.shortDescription: Merck and the Ministry of Health of the People's Republic of China establish the Comprehensive HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control Cooperative Project.
event.fullDescription: The Ministry of Health of the People's Republic of China and Merck & Co., Inc. officially establish the Comprehensive HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control Cooperative Project, a public-private partnership for HIV/AIDS prevention, treatment and care in China.

event.name: The Merck Childhood Asthma Network awards $10 million in grants
event.shortDescription: The Merck Childhood Asthma Network awards $10 million in grants to major urban areas facing health disparities.
event.fullDescription:
2005
The Merck Childhood Asthma Network awards $10 million in grants to five innovative asthma programs in Chicago, Los Angeles, New York City, Philadelphia, and San Juan, Puerto Rico. The programs aim to help low-income, urban populations with high rates of pediatric asthma.

event.name: JANUVIA (sitagliptin) is approved by the FDA
event.shortDescription: The FDA approves JANUVIA (sitagliptin).
event.fullDescription: The FDA approves JANUVIA (sitagliptin).

event.name: GARDASIL [Human Papillomavirus Quadrivalent (Types 6, 11, 16, and 18) Vaccine, Recombinant] is approved by the FDA
event.shortDescription: The FDA approves GARDASIL [Human Papillomavirus Quadrivalent (Types 6, 11, 16, and 18) Vaccine, Recombinant].
event.fullDescription:
The FDA approves GARDASIL [Human Papillomavirus Quadrivalent (Types 6, 11, 16, and 18) Vaccine, Recombinant].

Learn more – Vaccines: Our History, Our Legacy

event.name: Schering-Plough and Organon BioSciences NV become one company
event.shortDescription: Schering-Plough and Organon BioSciences NV become one company.
event.fullDescription: Schering-Plough and Organon BioSciences NV become one company.

event.name: Merck and Schering-Plough announce plans to merge
event.shortDescription: Merck and Schering-Plough announce plans to merge.
event.fullDescription: Merck and Schering-Plough announce that their Boards of Directors have unanimously approved a merger agreement under which the two companies will combine under the name Merck. Merck Chairman, President and CEO Richard T. Clark will lead the combined company.

event.name: Merck introduces The Merck Manual Home Health Handbook and iPhone application
event.shortDescription: Merck introduces The Merck Manual Home Health Handbook and iPhone application for The Merck Manual - Home Edition.
event.fullDescription:
2009
Merck releases The Merck Manual Home Health Handbook and an iPhone application, The Merck Manual - Home Edition. The Merck Manual Home Health Handbook is one of the most comprehensive medical books addressing health issues across all stages of life.

event.name: Merck named a top company for executive women
event.shortDescription: Merck named a top company for executive women.
event.fullDescription: The National Association for Female Executives names Merck to its "Top Companies for Executive Women" list for the first time.

event.name: The Merck U.S. Patient Assistance Program is significantly expanded
event.shortDescription: The Merck U.S. Patient Assistance Program is significantly expanded
event.fullDescription: More than 50 years after it was first established Merck significantly expanded the number of medicines available through its Merck Helps™ patient assistance programs. That is why the company provides certain medicines and adult vaccines for free to eligible individuals who do not have prescription drug or health coverage.

event.name: Kenneth C. Frazier becomes CEO of Merck & Co., Inc.
event.shortDescription: Kenneth C. Frazier succeeds Richard T. Clark as Merck's new CEO.
event.fullDescription:
2011
Kenneth C. Frazier succeeds Richard T. Clark as Merck's new CEO.

event.name: Merck launches its Merck for Mothers initiative
event.shortDescription: Merck launches its Merck for Mothers initiative to save the lives of mothers.
event.fullDescription:
2011
Merck launches the 10-year Merck for Mothers initiative, a global effort to bring the issue of maternal mortality to the forefront of global consciousness, develop new technologies and provide lifesaving solutions to women around the world.

event.name: The Mectizan Donation Program celebrates its 25th anniversary
event.shortDescription: The Mectizan Donation Program celebrates its 25th anniversary.
event.fullDescription:
2012
The Mectizan Donation Program celebrates its 25th anniversary. With the efforts of a variety of partners, including Merck's donation of more than 1 billion treatments of Mectizan to more than 117,000 communities in 28 countries in Africa, six countries in Latin America, and in Yemen, river blindness disease transmission has been interrupted – meaning no new cases have been identified – in four of the six affected countries in Latin America and nine regions in five African countries. Merck CEO Ken Frazier and former CEO Roy Vagelos participate in anniversary celebrations.

event.name: Merck for Mothers launches India initiative to help reduce maternal mortality
event.shortDescription: Merck for Mothers launches India initiative to help reduce maternal mortality.
event.fullDescription:
2013
Merck for Mothers launches its India initiative. It partners with three leading non-governmental organizations to improve the quality of healthcare that pregnant women in India receive through the private sector.

event.name: Merck applauds Colombia for verification of elimination of river blindness
event.shortDescription: Merck applauds Colombia for verification of elimination of river blindness.
event.fullDescription: Merck applauds the government of Colombia, whose work with the MECTIZAN Donation Program and The Carter Center-sponsored Onchocerciasis Elimination Program for the Americas led to the Pan American Health Organization, the World Health Organization's Regional Office for the Americas (PAHO/WHO), verification of Colombia as the first country in the world to eliminate the transmission of river blindness (onchocerciasis), using MECTIZAN® (ivermectin). Onchocerciasis is one of the leading causes of preventable blindness worldwide.

event.name: Merck completes acquisition of Idenix
event.shortDescription: Merck completes acquisition of Idenix.
event.fullDescription: Merck completes tender offer to acquire Idenix.

event.name: FDA approves BELSOMRA® (suvorexant)
event.shortDescription: FDA approves BELSOMRA® (suvorexant).
event.fullDescription: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approves BELSOMRA® (suvorexant).

event.name: Merck receives accelerated approval of KEYTRUDA® (pembrolizumab)
event.shortDescription: Merck receives accelerated approval of KEYTRUDA® (pembrolizumab).
event.fullDescription: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approves KEYTRUDA® (pembrolizumab). It had previously received breakthrough therapy designation from the FDA.

event.name: Merck completes sale of consumer care business to Bayer AG for $14.2 billion
event.shortDescription: Merck completes sale of consumer care business to Bayer AG for $14.2 billion.
event.fullDescription: Merck announces completion of the sale of the Merck Consumer Care (MCC) business to Bayer AG. Bayer acquires Merck's over-the-counter business, including the global trademark and prescription rights for CLARITIN and AFRIN, for $14.2 billion.

event.name: Merck congratulates Ecuador as second country to receive PAHO/WHO verification of elimination of river blindness
event.shortDescription: Merck congratulates Ecuador as second country to receive PAHO/WHO verification of elimination of river blindness.
event.fullDescription:
2014
Merck applauds the government of Ecuador on being the second country in the world to receive World Health Organization (WHO) verification of the elimination of river blindness (onchocerciasis) using MECTIZAN® (ivermectin).

Ecuador worked in partnership with the MECTIZAN Donation Program and The Carter Center-sponsored Onchocerciasis Elimination Program for the Americas, as well as the Pan American Health Organization, the Regional Office for the Americas of the World Health Organization (PAHO/WHO), to eliminate onchocerciasis – one of the leading causes of preventable blindness worldwide.

event.name: FDA approves GARDASIL®9 (Human Papillomavirus 9-valent Vaccine, Recombinant)
event.shortDescription: FDA approves GARDASIL®9 (Human Papillomavirus 9-valent Vaccine, Recombinant).
event.fullDescription: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approves GARDASIL®9 (Human Papillomavirus 9-valent Vaccine, Recombinant).

event.name: Merck completes tender offer to acquire Cubist Pharmaceuticals
event.shortDescription: Merck completes tender offer to acquire Cubist Pharmaceuticals.
event.fullDescription:
2015
Merck completes the tender offer to acquire Cubist Pharmaceuticals, Inc. Cubist becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of Merck, augmenting Merck’s strong foundation and opportunity for growth in the hospital acute care market.
